description: Easy - Carthage's Recovery and Mercenary Crisis

questions.question: What was Carthage's most significant problem immediately after losing the First Punic War in 241 BCE?
options: Rome invaded North Africa and occupied Carthaginian territory militarily
Carthage had to pay a massive war indemnity while its treasury was depleted
Sicily's loss eliminated Carthaginian naval dominance completely and permanently
Carthaginian citizens refused to participate in military campaigns any longer
questions.text_reference: Section 2: The Financial Burden and Internal Crisis

questions.question: Why did Rome rely on citizen soldiers while Carthage relied on mercenary armies militarily?
options: Carthage lacked enough population to field adequate citizen-soldier forces
Rome had no wealthy merchant families while Carthage had many such families
Carthage's aristocrats had no tradition of military service as civic obligation
Rome's island location prevented recruitment of foreign mercenary soldiers
questions.text_reference: Section 2: Roman vs. Carthaginian Military Systems

questions.question: What was the critical weakness of Carthage's mercenary military system?
options: Mercenary soldiers were less skilled than citizen-soldiers in combat operations
Mercenaries refused to fight at sea and only participated in land warfare
Mercenaries could not be disciplined effectively by Carthaginian military officers
Mercenaries required payment and had no political loyalty beyond receiving wages
questions.text_reference: Section 2: Roman vs. Carthaginian Military Systems

questions.question: What diverse groups of soldiers composed Carthage's mercenary armies after the First Punic War?
options: Only North African soldiers who were trained exclusively in defensive operations
Libyan infantry, Spanish warriors, Greek soldiers, and Numidian cavalry forces
Exclusively Roman defectors who had switched allegiance to Carthage militarily
Local Egyptian and Levantine troops who had served under Alexander the Great previously

questions.question: Who led the mercenary rebellion against Carthage starting in 240 BCE?
options: A Carthaginian aristocrat who sought to overthrow the government politically
Matho, a military commander of possibly Libyan or Numidian origin
A Roman general who infiltrated Carthaginian forces and incited rebellion
Hamilcar Barca, who opposed the Carthaginian government's policies militarily

questions.question: What was the Mercenary War also called due to its geographic location?
options: The Spanish War, because it occurred in Carthaginian territories in Iberia
The Mediterranean War, because it involved naval operations throughout the sea
The Libyan War, because it was fought primarily in Libya and North Africa
The Sicilian War, because it threatened Carthaginian control of the island

questions.question: What broader social forces supported the mercenary rebellion against Carthage militarily?
options: Subjugated Libyan peoples who resented Carthaginian rule and sought independence
Greek cities that opposed Carthaginian expansion into Mediterranean territories
Roman allies who wanted to weaken Carthage before the next war eventually
Egyptian forces that sought control of North African territories and resources

questions.question: What happened to Matho after Carthage suppressed the mercenary rebellion around 238 BCE?
options: He was exiled from Carthaginian territories and settled in a distant location
He negotiated peace and was accepted back into Carthaginian military service
He was executed in a particularly horrific manner as a warning to others
He escaped to Rome and sought alliance with Roman military leadership

questions.question: What fundamental weakness did the Mercenary War expose about Carthaginian military power?
options: Carthaginian soldiers lacked courage and commitment to military service generally
Carthage's mercenary system lacked the stability of Rome's citizen-based armies
Carthaginian officers were incompetent and unable to lead military forces effectively
Carthage lacked sufficient resources to pay soldiers for extended military campaigns

questions.question: What strategic decision did Carthage make to recover its power after the Mercenary War?
options: Carthage attempted to reconquer Sicily from Rome militarily and recover lost territory
Carthage built a larger navy to challenge Rome's naval dominance at sea
Carthage formed alliances with Egypt and Hellenistic kingdoms against Rome
Carthage focused on developing and conquering Spain for mineral wealth and manpower
